prerequisite.div: Senior standing; JOUR major; candidate for degree.

div.em: All seniors must complete an exit interview to remain eligible for graduation. JOUR 098 uses Blackboard. JOUR 098 is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: Appropriate career-related announcements, activities, and responsibilities.

notes.div: Open to non-College of Journalism and Mass Communications majors.

description.div: Introduction to the mass media as sources of news and entertainment conduits for messages of persuasion. Background and history about print and broadcast media and about public relations. How the media and persuasive messages both affect and are affected by society and content.

prerequisite.div: Major in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications or major in other colleges whose programs require JOUR 102; passing grade on the "Writing/Usage" proficiency exam.

notes.div: Arrangements for the "Writing/Usage" proficiency exam can be made in ANDN 147.

div.span: Basic principles of creating and evaluating clear, engaging expository, descriptive, narrative and persuasive writing for defined audiences and the contribution that tight focus, effective transitions, proper grammar, spelling, usage and punctuation make to effective writing.

prerequisite.div: ARTP: Art major or candidate for teaching endorsement in art. ARCH: Admission to the College of Architecture. IDES: Admission to the College of Architecture. JOUR: College of Journalism and Mass Communications major and 2.75 GPA. LARC: Admission to the College of Architecture. TXCD: Textiles, Clothing and Design major or minor.

description.div: Images change perceptions, the historic and economic underpinnings of visual communications, and the effects of images on individuals and groups. Advertising, typography, graphic design, photography, television, video, motion pictures, cartoons and the Internet.

div.span: JOUR 162 is taught in three five-week modules. JOUR 162 is 'Letter grade only'.
Creating elements of visual storytelling using photography, videography, and graphic design.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation.

notes.div: One University Honors Seminar 189H is required of all students in the University Honors Program. JOUR 189H is open to University Honors Program students with any major and will count toward the degree in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications.

description.div: Topic varies.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 201 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 201 is 'Letter grade only'.

div.span: Evaluating stories for grammar, punctuation, accuracy. and fairness. Learning and applying AP style. Writing headlines and captions.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 202 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 202 is 'Letter grade only'.

div.span: Basic reporting and writing for all news media. Interviewing and gathering information from appropriate sources.

description.div: Introduction to techniques for gathering information for use in preparing news and advertising for public media.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 302 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 302 is 'Letter grade only'.

div.span: Advanced reporting and writing. Skills and techniques necessary to develop more complex stories for all platforms.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 303 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 303 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Refining of editing of news and feature stories for print and on-line media. Issues of ethics and news-editing.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 305 will appear on student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 305 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Intensive practice in writing magazine articles for the general and specialized markets. Writing techniques and research.

notes.div: JOUR 324 is 'Letter grade only'.

div.span: Feature writing with the objective of improving the ability to produce nonfiction news stories.

notes.div: JOUR 326 is 'Letter grade only'.

div.span: The importance of good sports reporting through clear writing and its importance to readers; the principles of different types of sports stories; how to think critically about sports media; and how the fundamentals of good reporting and writing apply to sports.

notes.div: JOUR 348 is 'Pass/No Pass only'.

description.div: An inside look at the news reporting business by hearing each week from working journalists at the Omaha World-Herald.

prerequisite.div: Completion of all 100- and 200-level courses required for a major in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications.

notes.div: JOUR 350 is required for NEWS major.

description.div: Producing a multimedia news product.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 386 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. JOUR 386 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Theories and principles of editing and designing magazines. Decisions regarding the format and breakdown of the magazine, editing and designing stories, choosing photographs, writing captions and headlines.

div.em: Work in JOUR 401/801 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. Jour 401/801 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Long-form writing, interviewing, computer-generated research, refined writing and teamwork in the creation of a single-subject project.

div.em: Work in JOUR 801 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site.

notes.div: Student work in JOUR 404/804 will appear on student news World Wide Web (WWW) site.

description.div: News, feature, sports and picture-story journalism.

notes.div: Work in JOUR 406/806 will appear on the student news World Wide Web (WWW) site. Jour 406/806 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Building visual skills to recognize action, reaction and/or emotion, and incorporating them into the shootings and pictures.
Conduct investigative and in-depth reporting by using documents and computer databases, interviewing, and field research to write compelling stories.
Current issues in media and politics, domestically and internationally.

notes.div: JOUR 410/810 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Designing elements of news presentation, including newspapers, magazines, and web sites.
The roles and effects of mass media and major works exemplifying the practice of journalism.
Laws, regulations, and practices by which federal, state, and local government enhance or retard access to information about the executive, legislative, and judicial branches.

notes.div: Open to non-College of Journalism and Mass Communications majors.

description.div: Multicultural and gender diversity issues within the mass media. Broadcast news, print, and advertising media messages of racial, ethnic, and gender based minorities including African Americans, Hispanic Americans, Asian Americans, Native Americans, and women.

notes.div: Open to non-College of Journalism and Mass Communications majors. Articles will be submitted for publication.

description.div: Advanced writing about science for the non-expert and/or for the general audience. Issues in science communication through reading the best writers in science and journalism. Research and write short articles and longer profiles about science and scientists at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln (UNL) and elsewhere. Polish writing skills for doing work in science classes.

course.title: Cyberspace and Mass Media from the Grassroots

prerequisite.div: Senior in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications or graduate standing; 2.75 GPA.

notes.div: Students use the college Web site for laboratory experience.

description.div: Issues arising from the emergence of cyberspace, the trend toward globalization of mass media. Implications for journalism.

notes.div: JOUR 448 is for four students from a previous Real World I class who are chosen to participate in a fellowships at the Omaha World Herald newspaper. JOUR 448 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Fellowship at the Omaha World Herald newspaper.
Issues in sports media relations and integrated marketing communications. Background of the unpredictable nature of the sports industry and the relationships with its various publics and the media.

notes.div: JOUR 467/867 is open only to students seeking a grade 7 to 12 journalism teaching endorsement. JOUR 467 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Problems and procedures involved in producing school newspapers, yearbooks, literary magazines, and radio and/or video projects.

gradPrerequisite.div: Open only to students seeking a 7-12 journalism teaching endorsement

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; major in advertising, broadcasting, or news editorial; 2.75 GPA.

description.div: History of American mass media in cultural and philosophical contexts; the evolution of mass media as a social institution.

prerequisite.div: Junior standing; major in ADVT or BRDC or NEWS.

div.span: The legal basis for freedom of speech and press. The limitations imposed upon rights by statute, common law and court decisions. Resolving conflicts between those rights and other constitutional rights. Enhancing critical-thinking and writing skills. Roles, rights, and responsibilities of mass media in a free society through analysis of cases.

prerequisite.div: Senior standing; major in advertising, broadcasting, or news-editorial; 2.75 GPA.

notes.div: Required of all students seeking a degree through the College of Journalism and Mass Communications.

description.div: Interrelationships between the American mass media and society, integrating ethics, theories and contemporary issues.

notes.div: JOUR 491/891 may be repeated up to three times so long as the topics are different. JOUR 491/891 is 'Letter grade only'.

description.div: Topics vary each term.

notes.div: JOUR 496 is 'Letter grade only'.

prerequisite.div: Good standing in the University Honors Program or by invitation; candidate for degree with distinction or high distinction or highest distinction in the College of Journalism and Mass Communications.

notes.div: JOUR 499H is 'Letter grade only'.
